Title:
Development of SNP markers to infer evolutionary
relationships of Puccinia triticina
Keywords:
Single-nucleotide polymorphism, leaf rust, population,
evolution, house-keeping genes, simple sequence repeats
Abstract:
A panel of sixteen Puccinia triticina isolates selected
from worldwide populations from common and durum wheat were examined for
single nucleotide polymorphism in the intron regions of three house
keeping genes, elongation factor 1 (EF1-α), RNA polymerase II largest
subunit (RPB1) and the RNA polymerase II 2nd largest unit (RPB2) and
flanking regions of simple sequence repeats (SSR). An in silico approach
was also adopted to select SNPs based on the comparison of random
anonymous regions of sequences from four P. triticina genomes. The in
silico approach examining random anonymous regions proved more efficient
for finding SNPs than in the targeted loci. In total, fifteen pairs of
primers were designed for three house keeping genes (five pairs for
EF1-α, three for RPB1, and seven for RPB2), 32 pairs for 16 SSR loci,
and 17 for anonymous regions. After initial testing for success of PCR
amplification, one region for each house keeping gene, seven SSR
flanking regions and nine anonymous regions were selected for further
evaluation for SNPs. A total of 146 SNP sites were obtained: seven from
three house-keeping genes, 42 from seven SSR flanking regions and 97
sites were from nine anonymous regions. Based on the value of nucleotide
diversity (Pi), the anonymous regions were more variable compared to
other regions. Neutrality tests indicate all loci were not under strong
selection. A preliminary phylogenetic analysis of 16 P. triticina
isolates based on 146 SNP sites generally separated isolates from common
wheat from those on durum wheat as a distinct clade.
